newsitem.title: FRANCE: Transport strikes hit several French cities.
newsitem.headline: Transport strikes hit several French cities.

text.p: Strikes by public transport drivers demanding shorter working hours and early retirement disrupted services in several French provincial cities for the eighth consecutive day on Thursday.
The protests halted or disrupted buses, trams or underground railways in Lille, Rennes, Toulouse, Sete, Perpignan and several other cities.
In Toulouse, where the strike began three weeks ago, and in several other cities, transport authorities hired private buses to replace services affected by strikers.
The strike ended in Marseille on Wednesday and details of the agreement therewere expected to be published later on Thursday.
The striking drivers have been seeking a working week of 35 hours instead of 39 with no loss of pay and retirement at 55 instead of 60.
The stoppages, which began with a one-day protest in about 20 major cities last Thursday, have spared Paris where drivers are already entitled to retire at 55.

The government bowed to truckers' demands for retirement at 55 after they blocked roads late last year. But it opposes extending the concession, saying it could bankrupt the pension system when post-war baby boomers start swelling the ranks of pensioners from 2005.
